Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Grant for ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS) 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The annual ACM Computer and Communications Security (CCS) conference is a leading international forum for computer and communications security researchers, practitioners, developers, and users to explore cutting-edge ideas and results, and to exchange techniques, tools, and experiences. ACM CCS is the flagship event of ACM Special Interest Group of Security, Audit and Control (SIGSAC). Its acceptance rate is around 15-20%, which makes it a highly selective conference.

This grant provides support for 30 students to attend ACM CCS and associated workshops. Preference will be given to undergraduate students participating in the poster session, and students with papers in the conference or workshop who do not have other support. Participation by women and underrepresented groups will also be encouraged.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS) is the flagship annual conference of the Special Interest Group on Security, Audit and Control (SIGSAC) of the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM). ACM CCS facilitates quick and wide dissemination of cutting-edge research results and ideas in computer and communication security. Today’s students are tomorrow’s leaders. Providing them with an opportunity to enhance their skill sets is a direct investment towards a better future. Participation in the CCS conference and/or co-hosted workshops give students the opportunity to establish careers that focus efforts on the burgeoning area of computer and communications security. Students get an opportunity to showcase their research and an opportunity to network with established researchers in the area. The latter, in turn, opens up opportunities for the students of being mentored by leaders who have been engaged in the development of the science and initiating collaborative research with them. ACM CCS benefits by being able to ensure that research results are disseminated to the group that would benefit the most. In addition, being able to encourage and incentivize women and members of other minority groups to attend CCS, will bring in much needed diversity to the community. This grant gave 25 students opportunity to attend the CCS 2016 who wouldn’t have been able to attend without receiving travel grants from NSF.
